fields.Conference/Meeting Name: LACK, a new organization devoted to the promotion and development of Lacanian psychoanalytic theory
fields.Description/Abstract: This paper asks if we can understand the subaltern act in relation to Lacan’s theory of acts ? Drawing on textual moments from Rabindranath Tagore’s short story “Jibito O Mrito” (“Alive and Dead” [1892]), Gilles Pontecorvo’s 1969 film Quiemada (Burn!), Freud’s case study of the female homosexual (1920), and a short Indo-French documentary made in the 1970’s on the Sentinelese people of the Andaman Islands, I ask two interrelated questions. First, how can we read the subaltern act via Lacan, and, second, what are the radical implications of a violent subaltern acting out compared to the subaltern’s passage into death.
